_Technologies.Description: Assembled and ready to print ( some are locked to few materials from the machine supplier).

_Category.Description: An additive manufacturing method for fabricating tangiable products in 3 dimensions in various materials. If not stated otherwise, the part is build up layer by layer for each technology.

_SubCategory.Description:
Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) 
 - Commonly known as FDM, which is actually a Stratasys' trademark.
The material in shape of a strand, called filament, is extruded by a heated head typically controlled in y and x direction. This is by far the most well-known 3D-print technology. Surface finish, strength, precision etc. vary a depending on the machine quality and the users ability to adjust and replace components.
Synonyms: Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), Plastic Jet Printing (PJP)

_TrendTechnologies.Remark: High growth. Seems that after a slow start, personal 3D printer sales have grown a lot and will continue to do so
High growth. Linked to "online market place"

_Technology.Description: An online repository of 3D printable files that users can upload, discuss, and download. Ex: thingiverse, myminifactory, YouMagine, turbosquid...

_TrendTechnologies.Remark: High growth. Will be normal to order 3d printed parts/products from independant designers, that buys printer capacity from providers

_Technology.Description: Online market to buy and sell maker production (ex: etsy) or equipment for maker, ex: kickstarter (kickstarter is more and more beeing used as a standard distribution channel to introduce new products to makers ).

_TrendTechnologies.Remark: High growth. Instead of investing in a (mediocre) printer, some will buy it as a service in the future

_Technologies.Description: These printers is bought assembled, but is prepared for changes in hardware and software
These printers is bought unassembled, and most is prepared for changes in hardware and software, with this being open source.
EX: ember sla printer from Autodesk

_SubCategory.Description:
Stereolithography (SLA)
The part is built on a platform submerged in liquid photopolymer resin. The resin is exposed to a UV-laser where parts are build. SLA is known for its high level of detail, precision and smooth surface.
Synonyms: CLIP, SGC,

_Technologies.Description: Online platforms for the design of 3D models for mainly 3D printing and other manufacturing technologies like CNC milling. They often offer collaboration, discussion and sharing features.

Online CAD platforms combines traditional CAD software with the ability to cowork on a file alongside others and eliminates the need to keep track of updates, as the platform itself updates the newest version and make repositories of the old veersions. Some online CAD platforms also add advanced software, able to check files in order to ensure that an unfinished product won't enter production.

Online platforms for the design of 2D models for mainly laser cutting and other manufacturing technologies like CNC milling and vinyl cutting. They often offer collaboration, discussion and sharing features.

Online platforms for the design of electronics schematics and PCB for mainly prototpying with microcontrollers and the manufacturing of PCB with several technologies. They often offer collaboration, discussion and sharing features.

Programable system on board electronics used to read sensors input and control output actuators. Micro controler sytem on board, the microcontroller unit itself is usually not open source but all the schematics of the system on board are available and demonstrate how the micocontroller unit should be utilize. This makes it easy later on to port entire schematic on custom production PCB boards using the same components. ex: Arduino, BeagleBone Black, Netduino, Intel Galileo, Intel Edison...

_Category.Description: Technologies enabling building electronics devices (sensors, microcontrolers, actuators...)

_Technologies.Description: Online platforms that store and manage all the IoT data of your devices, projects, etc

_Category.Description: Network of physical objects—devices, vehicles, buildings and other items—embedded with electronics, software, sensors, and network connectivity that enables these objects to collect and exchange data.

_Trend.Name: Citizen Sensor Networks
_Trend.Description:
### Citizen Sensor Networks
“Trying to improve the control and optimization of urban behavior, city managers uniformly decided to invest in the improvement of the sensing infrastructures within the city. The penetration of mobile technologies have resulted in a massive data provision from their users, continuously sharing information anytime anywhere. The advantages of this continuous sensing capability are twofold:

– **Proactive  sensing**:  The  ability  to  share  information  through  the  mobile  devices combined with the humans’ “common sense” transforms any device-holder in a potential proactive intelligent sensor, which complements the classical continuous-sensing sensors installed in a certain location with an specific scope, whose performance is based on the detection of anomalous performances. Some successful applications within this line are SeeClickFix (where users can report about any type of infrastructure in the city) or Waze (this is a crowd-sourced navigator where the own users update the state of the traffic on the road in real time).

– **Passive sensing**: In the advent of the SmartCity Paradigm, one of the most challenging tasks to be solved is understanding the population distribution in real time. Such information would be of crucial importance for city managers as some of the services offered to the citizens could be tailored with complete information and in real time. Classical methods have profited from domain experts in the city or polling citizens to understand the needs of the citisens.

### Crowd Sourcing
The generalized use of the Internet and social network platforms has changed the way human beings establish relations, collaborate and share resources. In this context, crowd sourcing (or crowd computing) is becoming a common solution to provide answers to complex problems by automatically coordinating the potential of machines and human beings working together. Several challenges still separate crowd sourcing from its generalized acceptance by industry. For instance, the quality delivered by the workers in the crowd is crucial and depends on different aspects such as their skills, experience, commitment, etc. Trusting the individuals in a social network and their capacity to carry out the different tasks assigned to them becomes essential in speeding up the adoption of this new technology in industrial environments. Capacity to deliver on time, cost or confidentiality are just some other possible obstacles to be removed. In the main talk of this workshop, the plenary speaker Victor Muntés-Mulero, will discuss some of these issues, provide solutions to improve the quality in systems based on the use of crowd sourcing and present a real industrial problem where we use the crowd to leverage the work capacity of geographically distributed human beings. 

### Sensing the Citizens to Create a Smart Sensor Network:
Nowadays, many people have become Internet citizens or Web-enabled social citizens; the use of smartphones enables such citizens to easily connect to the Internet to up-load lot of data, this fact gives to such devices the ability to act as sensors. Thus, the term citizen-sensor network refers to an in terconnected network of people who actively observe, report, collect, analyze, and disseminate information via text, audio, or video messages. This combination of human-in-the-loop sensing, Web 2.0, and mobile computing has led to the emergence of several citizen-sensor networks. In particular, Web 2.0 fostered the open environment and applications for tagging, blogging, wikis, and social networking sites that have made information consumption, production, and sharing so incredibly easy. However, two significant developments in mobile computing helped enable citizen-sensor networks as we know them today: enhanced features such as GPS capability and cameras became a standard part of most mobile devices, and large companies created open mobile operating systems, such as Apple’s OS X for the iPhone and Google’s Android.”

### Creating a Smart Citizen Network with Smart Citizens Kit and Making Sense project
Smart Citizen is a platform to generate participatory processes of people in the cities. Connecting data, people and knowledge, the objective of the platform is to serve as a node for building productive and open indicators, and distributed tools, and thereafter the collective construction of the city for its own inhabitants.
The Smart Citizen project is based on geolocation, the Internet and free hardware and software for data collection and sharing. It connects people with their environment and their city to create more effective and optimized relationships between resources, technology, communities, services and events in the urban environment.
The Smart Citizen platform is a full set of of tools waiting from you to start using them: register to the platform, check the API, download the Android app, get a Kit or contribute to the open-source project.

The Smart Citizen Kit is a piece of hardware comprised of a sensor and a data-processing board, a battery and an enclousure. The first board carries sensors that measure air composition (CO and NO2), temperature, humidity, light intensity and sound levels. Once it’s set up, the device will stream data measured by the sensors over Wi-Fi using the FCC-certified, wireless module on the data-processing board. The device’s low power consumption allows for placing it on balconies and windowsills. Power to the device can be provided by a solar panel and/or battery. The Kit is not another black box, it is compatible with Arduino and all the design files are open-source (schematics and firmware). For more detailed hardware specifications visit https://docs.smartcitizen.me/#/start/hardware
The project is born within Fab Lab Barcelona at the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia, both focused centers on the impact of new technologies at different scales of human habitat, from the bits to geography. It also got founded thanks to lovely bakers on Kickstarter (2013) and Goteo (2012).
Making Sense is a European funded project that will run for two years between 2015 and 2017. The aim is to explore how open source software, open source hardware, digital maker practices and open design can be effectively used by local communities to fabricate their own sensing tools, make sense of their environments and address pressing environmental problems in air, water, soil and sound pollution.

The project will tackle that issues using three strategies. First of all, using open source technologies that gather environmental data with communities across Europe, they will be co-creating sensors & devices that use the Smart Citizen platform to capture environmental data. 
They will also enable and design platforms for collective sensemaking: testing tools and methodologies for making sense of data in pilots in Amsterdam, Barcelona  and Prishtina, and raising awareness of social and environmental issues.
The project will also take action by moving on a trajectory from awareness to positive change: with the pilot learnings they will develop the Making Sense toolkit  – a manual to organise citizen sensing campaigns for positive social change. And a Minimum Viable Open Manifesto to provide other projects and their communities with our own insights to better devise citizen engagement strategies and sustainable action plans. The process is currently open and ongoing and it accepts all contributions from all possible sources to keep on amassing new lessons. 

These are some lessons on the participatory and community building side of Making Sense, mainly harvested and developed from the activities and debates that took place in the past year: A MINIMUM VIABLE OPEN MANIFESTO
_Trend.References: Carelli, A., Bianchini, M., & Arquilla, V. (2014, June). The ‘Makers contradiction’: The shift from a counterculture-driven DIY production to a new form of DIY consumption. In 5th STS Italia Conference A Matter of Design: Making Society through Science and Technology.

Online platforms for sharing experience about projects, in order for the community to gain greater skill sets. These projects can relate to multiple different things such as; certain manufactoring techniques, certain products or even experience reaching a common goal. These platforms can be both extremely specialised, for instance forums dedicated to a certain 3D printer, or more generel with a more visionary goal such as shaping the future in a certain way (lower carbon footprint, greater wealth distribution, easier access to products etc.).

Public agencies and universities are increasingly sharing their work by making online repositories. It's often an one-way knowledge/file exchange as they do not allow the makers to modify the repositories, thereby making them exclusive. Very relevant in the empovering of makers to solve the worlds problems.

The collaboration on owned content is a concept where an owner of a file sets up a free download, but legally owns any change made to the file by users. For the industry this can give acces to a fast and versatile workforce. For a public domain it can let everyone have access to all current as well as future configurations of a file instead of any single person. For the maker it means easy access to high quality models.

A search engine for 3D models and other maker reletaed things. Sorting of information becomes increasingly relevant as the number of repositories grow. For the repositories this means that they dont have to attract a
The market places can sell both the 3D files and the printed parts but also connect customers with 3D printing companies.

The inclusive files repository differ from the exclusive variant in that it's just a platform for users to fill out. The repositories, made by users, can be private, open for a fixed number of people, open to everyone or even collaborated on (changes can be made to the repositories by multiple people). This creates a flexible platform for both singular users, groups and networks.
Customization software allows for consumers to make parametric changes to products before they buy. A parametric change could be scaling the size for instance.
Spreading the knowledge of projects and having the larger view on development helps solidify the maker movement.
The organisation search engine tries to make data available about organisations so that consumers/makers can make a consciouse choice
a directory which aims to provide tools and organisations for consumers to join the maker movement.
Online platform for sharing image content. This platform can be used to share maker instructions, set ups, product information or any maker related picture material.

Examples.Name: CTC Riverside and the Pegasus Touch

_SubCategory.Description:
Binder Jetting (BJ) 
Powder material (gypsum or plastic) is clued together with a binder extruded through print heads. These printers are often able to print in colours and the mechanism is very simple so they can be opened to any material. Parts are often fragile but can be strengthened with epoxy or similar.

_Category.Description: A laser cutter uses a high power laser beam to cut, carve or engrave in various materials, usually only in flat sheets. The cut-outs can be assembled to a 3D-model, if designed in such way.

Technologies.Description: Either a mini-computer or a powerfull micro controller, those devices are used control sensor and output actuators. Since they are quite powerfull for a microcontroller they allow a higher level of abstraction for the programing. ex: Raspberry Pi

Commons-based projects have less rigid hierarchical structures than those under traditional project models. Financial compemsation and sourcing of employees are also almost always vastly different from traditional models.
A wiki is a web application for collaboration on documents

Categories.Description: Milling is a konventional way of making functional parts with high precision and high level of detail. The part or the tool can be mounded on either a 3- or a 5-axis platform.

Using hardware is one of numorous ways to make a digital file in 2 or 3D. These applikations is controlled manually but the digital files size, shape and color are generated automaticlly by the device.
( to be moved: e.g. 3D scanners,  HP Sprout, coordinate measuring machine (cmm))

SubCategories.Description:
Selective Laser Sintering (SLS)
Plastic powder is melted together by a CO2 laser. Mirrors control the laser spot in Y and X direction. By scanning the powder surface several times a solid durable part is build up layer by layer. SLS is the only (or one of few) 3D print technologies that have absolutely no need for support structure while building durable parts. This allow the user to manufacture with completely free geometry.

Laminated Object Manufacturing (LOM)
Layers of paper, plastic or metal foil is glued together and cut by a knife or laser. This technology is not widely used though it is quite simple, mainly due to limited geometrical freedom - compared to other types of 3D printers.
Synonyms: Selective Deposition Laminiation (SDL)

Laser Melting (LM)
A fiber laser beam is controlled in Y and X direction by mirrors (scanning). This generates a melt pool (typically of 200 µm), which micro welds fine metal powder fully together, achieving mechanical properties comparable with traditional machined parts.
Synonyms: Selective Laser Melting (SLM), Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS), Laser Cusing

Cladding
Cladding is combining the basics of FDM in term of a moving print head with LM in term of strength. The print head is usually moved in multiple dimensions e.g. combined with a 5-axis cnc or on a robot arm. The 5 axis CNC platform allow alternately machining and fabrication and the robot arm allow manufacturing of extraordinary large parts. Both techniques enables deposition in all direction and is not restricted to solely Z-direction. The printhead deposits melted material on a solidified surface. The feedstock can be either metal wire or powder, which is melted by an electronic beam or a laser.
Synonyms: Laser Cladding, Directed Energy Deposition (DED), Laser Metal Deposition, Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS)

Material Jetting (MJ)
For this technology, all material is extruded from a printhead, in contrast to BJ, but stil similar with a injektion print head.

RadarInput.Description: Most 3D printers is sold as this type, but most makers feels locked down with no possibility to change and fine tune build parameters, software or hardware and limited to a few materials. Makers using these machines only wants to produce parts and have no desire to tweek, fine tune or even change components.

Scores.Title: Category
Scores.Description: An additive manufacturing method for fabricating tangiable products in 3 dimensions in various materials. If not stated otherwise, the part is build up layer by layer for each technology.

Scores.Title: SubCategory
Scores.Description:
Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) 
 - Commonly known as FDM, which is actually a Stratasys' trademark.
The material in shape of a strand, called filament, is extruded by a heated head typically controlled in y and x direction. This is by far the most well-known 3D-print technology. Surface finish, strength, precision etc. vary a depending on the machine quality and the users ability to adjust and replace components.
Synonyms: Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), Plastic Jet Printing (PJP)

RadarInput.Examples: Makerbot - Replicator 5th Gen [http://store.makerbot.com/replicator], UP Plus [https://www.up3d.com/], 3D Touch [https://www.up3d.com/]

RadarInput.Description: In general, FDM is the most commonly used technology and for the consumer "Plug and Play" is the only applicable kind. 3D printing have not shown its full capability for this user yet, but FDM is the closest one to do so.

RadarInput.Description: Programable system on board electronics used to read sensors input and control output actuators. Micro controler sytem on board, the microcontroller unit itself is usually not open source but all the schematics of the system on board are available and demonstrate how the micocontroller unit should be utilize. This makes it easy later on to port entire schematic on custom production PCB boards using the same components.

When selling it is just another distribution channel to get early feedback on product introduction. When buying it is a way to find interesting products to commercialize.

RadarInput.Description: Online platforms for sharing experience about projects, in order for the community to gain greater skill sets. These projects can relate to multiple different things such as; certain manufactoring techniques, certain products or even experience reaching a common goal. These platforms can be both extremely specialised, for instance forums dedicated to a certain 3D printer, or more generel with a more visionary goal such as shaping the future in a certain way (lower carbon footprint, greater wealth distribution, easier access to products etc.).

Public agencies and universities are increasingly sharing their work by making online repositories. It's often an one-way knowledge/file exchange as they do not allow the makers to modify the repositories, thereby making them exclusive. Very relevant in the empovering of makers to solve the worlds problems.

The collaboration on owned content is a concept where an owner of a file sets up a free download, but legally owns any change made to the file by users. For the industry this can give acces to a fast and versatile workforce. For a public domain it can let everyone have access to all current as well as future configurations of a file instead of any single person. For the maker it means easy access to high quality models.

The inclusive files repository differ from the exclusive variant in that it's just a platform for users to fill out. The repositories, made by users, can be private, open for a fixed number of people, open to everyone or even collaborated on (changes can be made to the repositories by multiple people). This creates a flexible platform for both singular users, groups and networks.

RadarInput.Description: Online CAD platforms combines traditional CAD software with the ability to cowork on a file alongside others and eliminates the need to keep track of updates, as the platform itself updates the newest version and make repositories of the old veersions. Some online CAD platforms also add advanced software, able to check files in order to ensure that an unfinished product won't enter production.
